title: Friday, 15th March 2019
bodyHTML:
DJ Morning!
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Again and again and again, you said the anger would come back just as the Markets Live did. Hello.

Welcome along once more to an hour of typing and etc.

Manxish Morning all

We suspect the strategy with the Y will follow a similar trajectory to the 3, skimming the high end of the market with more profitable sales, as the company works to bring costs down and then in 2021 introduce more mainstream price points to drive a further competitive lead over traditional internal-combustion-based vehicles.

BE11:10am

Top Gear was tedious, wasn't it?

11:10 am

While details were limited in terms of cell configuration, we suspect the Y will share similar architecture in terms of on-board Si- based inverter and Gigafactory cell configuration.

Soundbuy @FATDAZ - RTN?

I mean, before they started pretending to blow things up and aiming the whole thing at seven-year-old boys.

While we anticipate that the Model Y will take time to be a meaningful contributor for Tesla 2021, we view the design and development as further evidence that the company is moving far faster than the legacy auto OEMs and still has a commanding lead in EVs.

OnYourRight Le Blanc is just not very interesting......... simples

We look to our March 29 Freemont investor bus tour to Tesla to gain more details around the Model Y, Model 3, and V3 supercharging, as well as perhaps Semi.

Flaneur I dont understand the antipathy towards Musk/Tesla. Can anyone explain the root of it?
BE11:12am

We continue to believe that the EV disruption is nearing an inflection higher and view Tesla as the primary beneficiary within the auto industry; maintain BUY rating and $450 price target.

cracklenpop All eyes on the Champions League draw in a mo....
11:12 am
BE11:12am

What even is a crossover CUV anyway?

BE11:12am

Here's RBC.

tangledodyssey Musk, antipathy....mystery?
BE11:13am

Model Y is a smaller CUV that seats 5. First versions (Long
Range, AWD and Performance) scheduled for delivery Fall 2020. Standard
Range for Spring 2021. Standard Range starts at $39k ($4k greater than M3 Standard Range) with a 230 miles range and 0-60 in 5.9 seconds. Long Range at $47k w/300 mile range and 5.5 0-60. AWD $51K 280 mile range and 4.8 0-60. Performance starts at $60k 280 mile range, 3.5 0-60. There is a 7 seat option ($3k) which came as a surprise to us but not available until 2021. We got a chance to ride in the vehicle and it seemed... very Model 3-ish, just a little bigger/roomier. Same interior/dash. Our driver mentioned
front seats are same as Model 3 but on risers. While the test car didn’t
have the 3rd row, it doesn’t look like there was a lot of room; certainly not
a comfortable fit. It did have that nice electric vehicle acceleration. We’d
also note the event felt a little more subdued that other Tesla events we
have attended.

Soundbuy Crappy Utility Vehicle?
FATDAZ @BE Compact Utility Vehicle I believe
Flaneur @tangle - sounds like a Pink Floyd concept album
Soundbuy My bad this time......
Grouchmonkey Morning non-brexiteers
11:13 am
BE11:14am

Wait, is the C for crossover? Did I just do an ATM Machine type thing?

Lemmy @tangle: sounds like an 80s aftershave ad slogan
BE11:14am

The Implications. Can order now with a $2.5k refundable payment. There
will of course be orders and cash will come in the door. However, even
though Model Y is a bigger market than M3, we believe orders could be
muted. The vehicle isn’t available for nearly two years and consumers
may realize that putting down money early for the Model 3 didn’t yield
many benefits. The question in our minds is how much does Model Y
cannibalize Model 3? We suspect it could be significant as globally CUVs
have become more popular than sedans. Which begs the question, why
show the vehicle now? We would have thought the reveal would have
been closer to start of production. Will some potential M3 buyers wait?
That said, this should be a more profitable vehicle than the Model 3 (just
as CUVs built off shared car platforms are more profitable for all OEMs).
For instance, the $47k LR Model Y costs $4k more than its Model 3 cousin
but we have to imagine costs are fairly similar. Recall, Elon indicated Model Y would be ~75% common with M3 (it felt/looked it).

OnYourRight Question: Are brexiteers a dieing breed?
cloudy @Flaneur - M is happy go lucky go anything he wants. Had a good start.
DJ @OnYourRight no, but maybe a dying breed
PBateman Buenos días
cracklenpop Liverpool v Porto, Ajax v Juve

Mouselet Sorry to bother you, I forgot that I'd asked before :(
BE11:23am

It’s been a busy few months for The Restaurant Group. The acquisition of Wagamama has materially changed the composition of the business, creating a new avenue for growth to complement that of the pubs and
concessions, and counteract the more challenging trading conditions faced by the legacy Leisure brands. Following the completion of the acquisition, TRG’s CEO resigned and a search is underway to appoint a successor. How TRG will look in 2019 is very different, then, to how it looked for most of 2018. From a trading
perspective, 2018 was certainly a difficult year, but this was much as we had anticipated. LFL sales growth was
(2.0)%, which was in line with our estimate. Adjusted PBT was down 8% to £53.2 million, 4% above our
estimate, although a prior year asset impairment meant 2018 depreciation was reduced by £2.2 million, normalising for which adjusted PBT was £51.0 million, in line with our estimate of £51.2 million. Around 70% of outlet EBITDA now comes from the high-growth parts of TRG (Wagamama, pubs and concessions) and the
company continues to launch new initiatives to ensure this growth is sustained. LFLs at the group level were 2.8% in the first 10 weeks of the year, which includes Wagamama. Our FY19 adjusted PBT estimate (before any start-up costs for new initiatives) is £81.1 million.

Mouselet Wagamama at least has a half-plausible reputation and you might voluntarily go there with the main problem being that it's often too busy ... F&B's does not have that issue
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Wagamama delivering in its first few months. Wagamama’s LFL sales growth was 9.1% in the 12 weeks to 3 February. A number of initiatives to sustain market-leading growth rates are in the works, which include 3-4 new openings and six major refurbishments along with the conversion of 8 TRG Leisure sites to the brand (of a total of 15 conversions expected over two years). Wagamama will open a concession in Heathrow Terminal 3 in H2 2019 and one in Manchester Airport in 2020. TRG has now given a name to its start-up food-to-go concept – ‘Mamago’ – the initial pilot for which will be launched in H2 2019. TRG has reconfirmed its expectation of £15 million in cost synergies and £7 million revenue benefit from conversions by 2021.

Viking1 Perhaps apply city pub group valuation to their pub division ?

Mouselet Are we actually confident that the government as presently composed has set up a competent living-will process for Interserve so it won't blow away in a cloud of dead leaves and starving dementia patients?
BE11:27am

Anyway, one swallow and all that. Here's Peel Hunt.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

LFL sales are critical to the company. Within the current trading, Wagamama’s inclusion is a major boost, as it generated 9.1% LFL sales
growth in the 12 weeks up to 3 February. There are two problems with this:
(1) we estimate LFL sales in the rest of the company were only flat against a -5.5% comp; and (2) Wagamama’s LFL sales slowed from 12% in Q2 to 9%
in Q3 (ending 3 February). Our c2.5% LFL sales forecasts leave no room for
Wagamama to slow; the company will need almost 2% LFL sales growth to
cover just labour cost inflation. We view the shares as being inexpensive, but with too much risk to buy.

Tom Dalgleish Do a Christo job with it
Mouselet I went to Creams, a dessert-restaurant chain that just opened in Cambridge. The desserts were unpleasant and the clientele, umm, err, definitely the Primark demographic
undefined

Creditors may have already pre-funded a new facility into escrow ready to inject upon admin, who knows

So is he going to take private? Or is he buying to put a floor on the stock by cultivating the possibility that he might take private? I don't know.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Here's RBC.

BE11:34am

Q1 sales are SEK51.0bn ahead of our SEK49.9bn estimate, driven by a higher than expected positive currency effect. This implies that sales in local currencies are +4% yoy for February and Q1, with LFL sales very small positive yoy.

Some of H&M’s major markets have seen a strong end to the quarter, given very cold temperatures in major European markets last year. However H&M’s February sales are likely to have been constrained by a cautious ramp up of H&M’s new online platform in Germany and a positive effect in January from the earlier timing of Chinese new year, which reversed in February.

H&M will report its Q1 results on March 29 and then it is hosting a “Change Makers Lab” event on April 5 in Berlin, looking at how AI is used in the business and how this can be used to help improve sustainability.

We expect profitability in Q1 to be impacted at the gross margin level by further investments in the offer and logistics investments, and opex is likely to be inflated by further expansion of H&M Club during the period. We expect inventories to remain high but for the composition to be improving gradually, with a higher amount of fresh garments in the mix.

BE11:35am

RBC Fundamental View

We recently upgraded H&M to Sector Perform as we expect H&M's market share to stabilise in major markets and falling capital intensity to support its cashflow and dividend. We think H&M is making progress in improving its product and omnichannel offer which should lead to an improvement in sales and margins over time. Sentiment remains dour but valuation is not yet compelling enough to be more positive.

H&M trades at c.20x CY19e P/E or 8.5x lease-adj.EV/EBITDAR which reflects in our view some prospects for recovery. Although the Persson family has been buying more shares than usual over the past year, we think the prospects of H&M being taken private are unlikely (example of take-private media reports – Reuters Sept 2018). The company has not commented on these reports.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

One key point, it seems to us, is that the long-awaited results of the 9 month long inquiry by Rajah and Tann has been rather superceded by events. They can now say more or less what they like, it is not about legal opinions from influenceable 3rd parties any more, we have moved on the Singapore Police and “arrestable offences”. The company’s rather bizarre statement yesterday that an internal probe has found Mr Kurniawan to be exonerated did not cut the mustard with the market. The stock sank 8% after the headline spike. From where we are sitting this is beginning to look like the end game with a complete crisis of confidence leading to total disbelief in more or less anything the management say. The only good news really is that HF’s are prevented from adding to short positions for now. If there was a “normal” market in the stock it would clearly be below 100 by now rather than the 115 level where it closed. We remain sellers.

Grouchmonkey agh I hate that. "Superseded" please
BE11:42am

You also have Citigroup throwing in the towel.

BE11:43am

Downgrade to Sell

Our caution regarding Wirecard to date has been based on financial disclosure (see note) and risks inherent in the business model (see note and note). Given the various developments since the beginning of the year, our view has turned more cautious as we believe the market is now mispricing the risks associated with a prolonged period of uncertainty around the recent allegations made against the company in the press. As such, we downgrade Wirecard from Neutral to Sell.

FATDAZ @Wayne J :)

[T]he company has repeatedly stated that the allegations are false and (more significantly in our view) has pointed towards a quick resolution. In our opinion, the nature of the allegations, the complexity of the case and the reported scope of the investigation suggest that these allegations will likely take longer to resolve than what the market is currently pricing in.

BE11:57am

Great day yesterday - 4 goodish priced winners and two long odds places. Hope I don’t give it all back today!

1:30. SIR EREC the 5/6 fav should give Joseph O’Brien is 2nd winner here. But with Sky’s cash back offer emboldening me am going for an each way 10/1 QUEL DESTIN who has won his last 5.

2:10 Handicap - as usual very competitive. Coral pay 6, others 5 places. Narrowed down my picks from 8 to 4. CROOKS PEAK 11/1. MONSIEUR LECOQ 9/1and a couple of long-shots STERNRUBIN 28/1 and MAGIC DANCER 33/1.

2:40 Novice Hurdle - Corals paying 5. DERRINROSS 11/1, BIRCHDALE 5/1 & LISNAGAR OSCAR 7/1 all each way.

3:30 The Gold Cup - a truly open renewal this year. Lots paying 4 places. I am not betting Native River to repeat last year’s win and by all accounts will probably live to regret it. But have already done these ante-post so will stick with them. Odds quoted are today’s (ante-post were much longer). CLAN DES OBEAUX 5/1, KEMBOY 10/1 and BRISTOL DE MAI 25/1 all each way.

4:10 the Foxhunters chase. 4 places to be had generally. HAZEL HILL 5/1, SHANTOU FLYER 15/2 and ROAD TO ROME 8/1 - all each-way.

4:50 Grand Annual H'cap chase. BRELAN D’AS and Bryony to win again 10/1, NOT ANOTHER MUDDLE 5/1 and a roughie FOREST BIHAN 33/1 - all each way with most paying 5 places.

And if you are still going, the last of the festival 5:30. Conditional Jockeys … EARLY DOORS 9/2 to give Joseph a 3rd win and a roughie to end on BURROWS PARK 28/1 E-w, 5 places with Bet Victor.
